title: Pineapple Tallow Balm: My Weird Winter Skin Savior
body:
Okay so. My skin is a disaster. Like, a real piece of work. It’s winter, right? Which means my face is somehow both a flaky desert and an oil slick at the same time. My cheeks get so dry they feel tight, like I’m wearing a mask made of papier-mâché. But my forehead? Grease city. I’d wake up and it was shiny. I was using this expensive cream from that fancy store in the mall, you know the one with the blue jars. Fifty bucks. Felt nice going on. Did absolutely nothing. My hands were worse. Knuckles cracked and red, like I’d been punching a brick wall. I tried everything. Coconut oil (greasy mess). Shea butter (just sat on top). That thick white stuff in the tub (sticky, smelled like a hospital). Nothing worked. I was about to just give up and live in mittens.

Then I saw someone talking about tallow balm. Beef fat. For your face. I thought it was a joke. Like, what’s next, bacon conditioner? But I was desperate. And curious. The kind of curious you get at 1 AM when you’re scrolling on your phone and your cat is judging you from the arm of the couch. I found this little Etsy shop. They had a whipped tallow balm in a pineapple scent. Pineapple. In winter. It sounded ridiculous. And cheerful. I needed cheerful. So I ordered it. A whipped beef tallow balm, made from grass-fed suet or whatever, whipped up in France. I figured, worst case, I’d have a very expensive candle.

## Why I Even Tried Beef Tallow on My Face

Look, I get it. It sounds gross. Beef tallow for skin? You think of frying potatoes. Not your moisturizer. But the thing is, I read a bit while I was waiting for it to ship. Apparently, tallow is weirdly similar to the oils our own skin makes. Our sebum. So it doesn’t just sit there like an alien substance—it actually gets it. It absorbs. It’s like your skin recognizes it. That made a weird kind of sense to me. All those fancy creams with a million ingredients? My skin was probably like, “what is this chemical soup, no thank you.” But something simple, something almost primitive? Maybe.

It arrived on a Tuesday. It was cold out, the kind of cold that hurts your face when you walk to the car. The jar was small. Cute. I opened it. The texture was… not what I expected. It was whipped, like cool whip but denser. Solid but soft. I poked it. It held the fingerprint. Weird. I smelled it. Okay, here’s the pineapple tallow balm scent: it’s not a fake, sugary candy pineapple. It’s like… the idea of pineapple. With summer behind it. Tropical, but in a distant, happy memory way. Not overpowering. Just a bright little whiff. It made me smile, which was a good start.

I scooped a tiny bit. Rubbed it between my fingers. It melted immediately. Like, it went from solid to oil in two seconds. I put it on the back of my hand first. Cold at first. Then it just… vanished. Sunk right in. No greasy film. No shiny residue. My skin just drank it. It felt calm. Not “moisturized” in a heavy way. Just… normal. Like it was supposed to feel. I was shocked.

## How I Use This Tallow Balm (And What Actually Happened)

So that first night, I went for it. Washed my face. Dried it. Took a pea-sized amount of the tallow. Rubbed my palms together. Gently pressed it all over my face. Avoided my eyes, obviously. It felt… fine. A little slick for a minute, then it was just gone. I went to bed expecting to wake up a greaseball or with a whole new crop of zits.

I didn’t.

I woke up and my face felt… quiet. The tight, dry feeling on my cheeks was gone. Completely. My forehead wasn’t an oil slick. It was just skin. My first thought was “huh.” My second thought was to check the mirror. No new breakouts. The red, irritated patches near my nose looked less angry. I touched my cheek. It was soft. Not “product” soft. Just soft.

I started using it every night. And on my hands after every wash. My knuckles, man. They were a lost cause. But after about three days of putting this tallow balm on them, the cracks started to heal. The redness faded. It was the best natural moisturizer for my dry, combination mess of skin I’d ever found. I didn’t have to reapply my hand cream six times a day. Once in the morning, once at night. Done.

The real test was a week later. I had to be outside in the wind for like twenty minutes. Normally, that would set my face on fire with dryness for days. I came inside, my skin felt a bit wind-whipped, but not screaming. I put a little more of the balm on. It settled right down. It was like it had built up some kind of… I don’t know, barrier. A good one. Not a cloggy one. My skin just felt protected.

## My Skin Now (And the Weird Part No One Talks About)

I’m a month in. I’m maybe halfway through the jar. Here’s the honest take: my skin is balanced. That’s the only word for it. It’s not “perfect.” I still get the occasional stress pimple. But the wild extremes are gone. The desert-and-oil-slick situation is over. It’s just… skin. It feels healthy. It looks calm. When I put makeup on now, it doesn’t cling to dry patches or slide off by noon. It just sits there, like it’s supposed to.

But here’s the weird part no one mentions. It’s not a miracle *feeling*. You don’t put it on and get this luxurious, spa-like sensation. It’s not heavily perfumed. It doesn’t tingle. It’s functional. It’s like your skin goes, “oh, hey, thanks for the good stuff,” and then gets on with its day. You forget about it. And that, to me, is the sign of something that actually works. You stop thinking about your skin because it’s not causing problems anymore.

I told my sister about it. She has eczema on her elbows, really bad. I gave her a little bit of mine to try. She texted me two days later: “what is this wizardry.” Her elbows weren’t cured, but they were less itchy, less scaly. She ordered her own jar. For rough hands, for psoriasis patches, for just winter skin that’s pissed off—this might be the best tallow for those stubborn, dry concerns. It doesn’t play around.

Would I buy it again? I already did. I got a second jar last week because I never want to run out. I keep one in the bathroom and one in my bag. It’s that essential. I’ve spent more on a single dinner out than on this jar of tallow balm, and the dinner was gone in an hour. This has fixed my skin for a whole season.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, weirdly, it is. From what I understand, it’s super similar to the oils our skin already makes. So it absorbs deep instead of sitting on top and clogging things up. My face seems to think it’s the best thing ever.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Not for me, and I’m super prone to clogging. It’s non-comedogenic, which means it shouldn’t. It sinks in so completely there’s nothing left to clog with. If you’re worried, just start with a tiny bit.

**What does pineapple tallow balm smell like?**
It’s cheerful. Like a sunny day, but not in a fake, piña colada way. It’s a sweet fruit smell that’s bright and clean. Fades pretty quick after you put it on. Mostly you just smell… nothing, which is how I like it.

Anyway. If your skin is being difficult, if you’ve tried the fancy stuff and it’s not working, maybe give this a shot. I was super skeptical about putting beef fat on my face, but honestly? It just works. I don’t have a better explanation. My skin’s happy, I’m happy. That’s all I wanted. I got mine from this little Etsy shop that makes it, if you’re curious. Might be worth a look.
